I think this war has done something no other historical event has done in centuries, if ever. It has clearly split the world into the dark forces and the forces of light. 

That might sound like an oversimplification, but I assure you, it is not. 

After what Hamas did, if you stand anywhere besides right next to Israel, you are part of the forces of darkness. 

Period. 

It might not be politically correct to say, but if you side with Hamas, if you are glorifying Bin Laden, if you are chanting for the genocide of the Jewish people, if you are calling for Israel to cease its fire and let Hamas continue to exist, there really is no other way to say this and I‚Äôm sorry I have to be the one to tell you this, but you chose wrong. You chose evil. You are an accomplice to it all! 

It‚Äôs not too late to reconsider but if you don‚Äôt, and you stand against Israel now, you will be held accountable. 

Hamas has helped clear things up and now the world knows clearly who is good and who is evil. 

And thanks to the internet, there will be no denying where you stood. We see you and we won‚Äôt forget. 

Stand with justice. 

Stand with morality. 

Stand with humanity. 

Stand with Israel!

Yalla bye!

The entire framing of the conflict is so consistently dishonest and meant to drive certain narratives. 

The way much of the press downplay Oct 7th as just some data point in the conflict, instead of the worst terror attack in recent history. The way they pretend the ongoing conflict is one sided, ignoring the the thousands of rockets shot at Israeli cities constantly, hundreds of thousands of Israeli families that have left their homes and spend days in bomb sheltered, families still burying loved ones, hostages being kept by Hamas, young people now risking their lives to take on Hamas etc

And even just with Gaza: They take the Hamas death toll as fact (a mistake), but then also frame all the deaths as Israeli responsibility. No differentiation between Hamas terrorists killed Vs civilians. No differentiation between the countless civilians killed by Hamas/IJ (20-30% of rockets fall in Gaza) vs in Israeli strikes. No acknowledgement of Hamas‚Äô responsibility in hiding among civilians (a war crime) and trying to prevent them from leaving the war zone. 

Every single aspect of the framing is one-sided and then they use that framing to apply pressure on Israel to give Hamas an out.

HEROES: This 24-year-old girl, Captain Yuval, a logistics officer in the NAHAL Infantry Brigades found herself driving in her car in pajamas on OCT 7 racing to her unit at Kerem Shalom near GAZA & Egypt. Along the way, she was ambushed and killed 2 terrorists on motorbikes while firing a 9mm out the window and driving... ü§Ø 

With her unit non-responsive and mostly dead, when the extent of the event started becoming clear to her after seeing masses of terrorists, car after blown out car, and dead bodies everywhere, she gathered herself amidst the chaos and decided to set up an emergency command post nearby on a small farming community to re-organize what as left of her soldiers who had mostly been killed and bring in more. Her efforts included helicopter support and reservists coming in by rushed cellphone calls landing in the fields of the farming community.

They assembled a full combat field command post to enter the fighting, including by air and rescue Israelis under siege by Hamas, it was active FOR 2 WEEKS at the start of the war. üëÄ 

Captain Yuval, 24.
Have you ever heard so such a people as the nation of Israel?  üáÆüá±

Mali Shoshana - a hero. 

Police officer Mali Shoshana bravely led the battle against Hamas terrorists who infiltrated the city of Sderot on October 7, and eliminated at least 4 of them.

When the terrorists threw a grenade at her, she picked it up and threw it back. Even when her ammunition ran out, she didn't give up. She pretended to be dead, held her breath and survived until other security forces rescued her.

‚ÄúI still can't believe I'm alive. I asked my friends to tell my son that I love him‚Äù

This is Officer Mali. On 10/7 she & her team fought terrorists for hours from the roof of the Sderot police station.

When Hamas threw a grenade, she threw it back - killing two. 

When the officers ran low on ammo, they took it off the dead terrorists.

Fellow officers were killed around her & she was shot in the hand but kept fighting. ‚ÄúTell my son I love him‚Äù, she said on the radio. 

When Hamas made it to the roof, she survived by playing dead among the bodies of her friends.

I don‚Äôt have the details and I don‚Äôt know who he is or what the story was but I‚Äôm told it‚Äôs true. 

This solider carried around a book psalms with him and that book ended up saving his life by protecting him from a bullet. üáÆüá±‚ú°Ô∏è https://t.co/ALCF6JO2PV

On the morning of Oct 7, these four soldiers ‚Äì Idan, Elia, Ido and Nitzan ‚Äì heard gunshots. They climbed into their tank and advanced toward Gaza where they saw hundreds of terrorists spilling over the border. 

These four heroes fought for 24 hours, took out 80 terrorists, and prevented another massacre in nearby villages.

Meet Tali Hadad, Israeli hero and national treasure. 

Her son was injured by Hamas terrorists in Ofakim. Ignoring the danger, she rushed to pick him up and drive him to a medical center. 

Then she turned around and drove back toward the danger to rescue more of the injured. She made the trip 3 times under fire and ultimately saves 12 lives. 

Tali says: "I'm not comfortable with the word heroine. I am a responsible citizen. The real heroes are the soldiers.‚Äù

Trust us Tali, you‚Äôre a hero!

This hero is named Nasreen Yousef. 

On Oct 7, Nasreen walked out of her house to confront a terrorist who had infiltrated her community of Moshav Yated. While the local security team held him, she spoke to the terrorist in her native Arabic to understand how he got in and how many more terrorists were coming. 

At some point his phone rang and she answered it, convincing the terrorist on the line that she was an Arab willing to help. Nasreen gathered critical information that she passed along to the IDF who were able to prevent a bloodbath in Moshav Yated.

Nasreen is an incredible woman and hero of Israel üíô

Meet Michal Elon.

The mother of 10 works as a pediatric oncology nurse. On Oct 7, she and her family were at Zikim army base to be with soldiers during the Jewish holiday of Sukkot.

Early in the morning, sirens sounded and with horror, Michal and her husband realized that Hamas had infiltrated the base. They rushed their family to a shelter and took cover.

When a soldier was wounded, Michal left the safety of the shelter to try and save her life. As she was treating the head wound, a Hamas terrorist appeared at the door and shot her in the stomach, chest, and arm.  She used her headscarf as a tourniquet to stop the bleeding until she and her family could be rescued.

On the left is Noa, a combat soldier in the IDF. She got onto a public bus in Israel and sat next to the driver. They chatted and she shared a bit about her missions. She also mentioned that she had just left the field and hadn't had a chance to eat. 

The driver pulled over by a restaurant, took money from his pocket and told her: "There will be no hungry soldiers on my bus. With everything you do for the country, it's the least I can do for you. Now go get yourself some to eat.‚Äù 

The whole whole bus waited while Noa went to grab some food. She posted this photo and asked that we share this story to thank and celebrate this kind driver.
